hook.text: Two patients need the same kidney. One is a 10-year-old girl. The other is a 65-year-old former president.

buildup.text: Over 100,000 Americans are on the organ transplant waiting list. About 17 die each day waiting.

discovery.text: Allocation systems use medical urgency, time on waitlist, geographic proximity, and tissue matchâ€”not wealth or fame.

twist.text: But wealthy patients can list at multiple transplant centers across the country, effectively jumping the queue.

climax.text: Fair allocation requires resisting every instinct to value some lives over others based on status or money.

punchline.text: One kidney, two patients. The rules decide who lives.

quiz.question: How do organ allocation systems determine who receives a transplant?
options: Whoever can pay the most gets priority
A random lottery system with no medical criteria
